commits.message: Fix documentation links (#50695)
Fixed URL (#50690)
shims/scm: move to same path as Homebrew/brew.

Remove (almost) everything (#50678)

* cmd/help: tell people to run brew update.

* Remove (almost) all removable files.
Remove formulae/aliases/travis.yml. (#50676)
README: note migrations.

Update/split documentation.

Point to the new repositories instead.

update: fix hyphen counting (legacy tap renaming)

Fix regression introduced in b2c31074e786835b45d0d07ca156cd3fb1ce2a9f.
Backported from Homebrew/brew@500f9eada854c1939bf9a0caf94085214c9399b0.
Counting the number of hyphens in a string cannot be done in a single
expression, thus split this and introduce another local variable.

update: remove stray comma (legacy tap renaming)

Fix regression introduced in b2c31074e786835b45d0d07ca156cd3fb1ce2a9f.
Backported from Homebrew/brew@93e0f4f9465978460d411f27214e19ae3fc4d294.

Revert "test-bot: clean up on Jenkins before building PR"

This reverts commit 51e4e6490bda0d981afd1787a6392ab588b0601c. This did
not work as intended, as the `git` command is executed in the context of
the tap the current job operates on, never for Homebrew/homebrew itself.

test-bot: clean up on Jenkins before building PR

Wipe everything from the Homebrew prefix except for the `Library/Taps`
directory to avoid having to refetch `homebrew/core` every time.
README: clarify and improve human parseability (#50664)

CoreTap#install: fix clone target setting

When invoking `brew tap homebrew/core`, the input options will be like
`{ :clone_target => nil }`. This renders `Hash#merge` a dead operation.

It doesn't impact Homebrew itself, but could cause problem for
downstream projects Linuxbrew/Tigerbrew when they adopt core/formula
separation.

This commit is backported from
https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/commit/1b7e13df4f936dd318a23698b7b69bd2ca0e2487

nesc: assign minimum emacs version

On certain system(e.g. fe22f59), `brew update` will report
`Error: Specify a version for EmacsRequirement` before it could run
migration for brew 0.9.9.

This commit workaround this problem.

update: use --replace-all to set remote.origin.fetch

Otherwise, it will fail on users who have multiple entries on
remote.origin.fetch.

various: add remote migration hack

Depends on what local revision users start with, there will be
several places which can be used to trigger remote migrations.
 * `tap_migrations`: some old system will load `tap_migrations` during
   `brew update`
 * `formula_revision`: old system whose revision is after
    c010cc8a8cadfe2e29f541570b70e62b6d735fb9 but before
    ac5707c37470c25583d8fb712bf5dc04ab91db4b will load `formula_revision`
    during `brew update`. This will help to solve #42553 on these
    systems
 * `update-reporter`: system since we implement bash update script.

Closes #50653.

Signed-off-by: Xu Cheng <xucheng@me.com>
update: migrate to new remote

test-bot: fix path in cleanup_before

We should remove PR lock files in the test tap rather than HOMEBREW_REPOSITORY.
pull: fix --legacy when pulling bottle from new repo
test-bot: ensure tap is full clone
test-bot: fix CI upload for core tap
pull: auto fix legacy closes message
pull: fallback to old BrewTestBot git repo when necessary

test-bot: handle legacy formulae PR from Homebrew/homebrew

Closes #50635.

Signed-off-by: Xu Cheng <xucheng@me.com>

doc: update for core/formula separation

Closes #50632.

Signed-off-by: Xu Cheng <xucheng@me.com>

tap-(un)pin/untap: better error message

Closes #49904.

Signed-off-by: Xu Cheng <xucheng@me.com>

readme: clarify what's not in homebrew/brew

Closes #50661.
test-bot: exclude Taps dir from root cleanup

test-bot: have --cleanup clean core repo as well as tested tap

Fixes #50651

diagnostic: improve check for 'install_name_tool'

`install_name_tool` location depends on the location of the active developer
directory managed by `xcode-select`.

Closes #50509.

Signed-off-by: Mike McQuaid <mike@mikemcquaid.com>

Test this formula and it wasn't actually working properly as it was just installing the bin+lib to /usr/local rather than using ${prefix}.

Have fixed this and also updated it to the latest production release 8.16.

See http://gist.github.com/358902 for fixed version.

This is a brilliant formula to get working in homebrew.

Note that this is VirtualBox OSE (Open Source Edition) which the project owners do _not_ distribute builds for, nor do they provide an update mechanism for it.

Virtualbox.org only distributes binaries under a 'Personal Use and Evaluation' license, which prohibits any commercial use. So being able to install the OSE version from homebrew is a big step forward.

Could you make a suggestion how to unify the two formulas gnupg and gnupg2?

I merged the two formulas in one, as you suggested.
The option to build the GnuPG 1 version is --gnupg1.
The commit is: michelSt/homebrew@15a78a4365612b56a7a8d18d75a9715777e8f141

As you can read hear: http://lists.gnupg.org/pipermail/gnupg-announce/2007q2/000254.html gnupg 1 is not binary compatible with gnupg 2:

> GnuPG-2 has a different architecture than GnuPG-1 (e.g. 1.4.7) in that
> it splits up functionality into several modules.  However, both
> versions may be installed alongside without any conflict.  In fact,
> the gpg version from GnuPG-1 is able to make use of the gpg-agent as
> included in GnuPG-2 and allows for seamless passphrase caching.  The
> advantage of GnuPG-1 is its smaller size and the lack of dependency on
> other modules at run and build time.  We will keep maintaining GnuPG-1
> versions because they are very useful for small systems and for server
> based applications requiring only OpenPGP support.

In fact as far as i know the pinentry-mac formula i have written (see: ticket #1068) to support a gui for entering the passphrase only works with gnupg 2.

Should we make one formula as in commit michelSt/homebrew@15a78a4365612b56a7a8d18d75a9715777e8f141, or a separate one like in commit michelSt/homebrew@bb6357b8a34b0252cbc4912560912bffe599f2d8 ?

Bug confirmed. I have my homebrew install in a non standard location too (~/Homebrew) and exim fails to build.

GCC can't find the perl regexp library, although it was pulled in as a dependancy. You need to add the path to ~/.homebrew/include files to your CFLAGS. It is already there  in CXXFLAGS, but not in CFLAGS for some reason.

try applying this patch to Library/Homebrew/extend/ENV.rb and everything shoud work http://gist.github.com/417006
Yep, it's the same. Why not pull it into the main branch? Adding an extra include path won't break anything, and it's already there for cxx.
I guess we've got now a bug for this fix to fix 8-)

```
diff --git a/Library/Formula/libebml.rb b/Library/Formula/libebml.rb
index 1eca26f..402d780 100644

+++ b/Library/Formula/libebml.rb
@@ -3,9 +3,9 @@ require 'formula'

   def install

+  md5 '4efcf3945b17a6f0320cf1aaa326a4de'

   depends_on 'libebml'

diff --git a/Library/Formula/mkvtoolnix.rb b/Library/Formula/mkvtoolnix.rb
index 63ae4de..e1fb418 100644
--- a/Library/Formula/mkvtoolnix.rb
+++ b/Library/Formula/mkvtoolnix.rb
@@ -1,9 +1,9 @@
 require 'formula'

 class Mkvtoolnix <Formula
-  url 'http://www.bunkus.org/videotools/mkvtoolnix/sources/mkvtoolnix-3.3.0.tar.bz2'
+  url 'http://www.bunkus.org/videotools/mkvtoolnix/sources/mkvtoolnix-4.0.0.tar.bz2'

+  md5 '434eb24b9c49a99ac386bd2c4c525538'

   depends_on 'boost'
   depends_on 'libvorbis'
@@ -17,10 +17,12 @@ class Mkvtoolnix <Formula
       %q!sed -e 's:\\.\\(o\\|gch\\)$:.d:'!,
       %q!sed -E -e 's:\\.(o|gch)$:.d:'!

+    boost_flag = "--with-boost-libdir=#{HOMEBREW_PREFIX}/lib"
     flac_flag = Formula.factory('flac').installed? ? "--with-flac" : "--without-flac"

     system "./configure", "--disable-debug",
                           "--prefix=#{prefix}",
+                          boost_flag,
                           "--with-boost-regex=boost_regex-mt", # via macports
                           flac_flag,
                           "--disable-gui", "--disable-wxwidgets"
```

commit_comments.body: No method "extract_names"?
This should be disabled during --debug mode; ruby chews up CPU while you're dinking around figuring out while a build failed.
I was seeing more like 5%, for some reason.
For the record, I do like this feature, and it's not like I'm debugging formulas constantly.

@alloy turns out I had several failed terminal windows open at once; if I only leave one up the CPU usage is ~1%, if that.
Sorry!

This doesn't work if you have for instance:
EDITOR='mate -w'

I guess I'm living in a non-command-line world if this is the first breakage I've noticed. Thanks for the symlink tip.

(It might help if "The Internet" wasn't recommending "mate -w" as the editor, I suppose.)
If the OS X version is available to the test suite, then add "if os x is >= 10.6" around the "assert arches.include?(:x86_64)" line and then we'll be good on 10.5 as well.

review_comments.body: Not if you're using it in `def install`, as here,  though you may if you're using it outside of that method call I think.

commit_comments.body: Should be extract_named_args, not sure how I managed to not test that. Apologies

I agree, it seems reasonable to expect devs to have the github config, especially in lieu of this feature.

Also I'm not sure the above code is guaranteed to work if you have more than one remote.

Personally I don't much see the point of a test that just duplicates a big case statement. But I did add a test to ensure that it returns something valid on the system that is tested, I'm happy with that. What do you think though? I believe I pushed it.
Hmm you can tell I've been up for 20 hours, this is that commit! lol.

I think Adam means when Homebrew rescues the build to a new interactive shell. But well, I think it's still useful then.

I'm a little surprised it uses so much CPU, it should be a socket-based event loop.

Firstly irc is freenode.net #machomebrew

I moved it to install because for efficiency reasons it seemed unecessary to start and stop the fsevents watcher multiple times. As, and correct me if wrong, the install-just-one is 99% of the install loop that the spill() function wraps.

I believe with the current argument, moving it to install-just-one wouldn't make a difference anyway as the interactive shell part is inside that block. So the results would be the same for both situations.

So in conclusion, in order to stop it watching when interactive shell is open we need more work anyway.

And my opinion: it's not worth it. I agree it sucks to drain CPU for nothing. But it's for a minority use case, and it's only a few percent for a small time. If we ever figure out an elegant solution it would be worth changing the code, but as it stands, we don't have one.

Although as I think more on it, the spill function should only surround the brew section anyway. We may want to move it into Formula.

However I should reiterate, this won't fix the problem above as the interactive shell is still further in (see brew.h.rb install())

Also to add more words to this issue (apologies!), really the fsvents loop has to surround the shell anyway, otherwise how could you be sure you haven't installed to somewhere you shouldn't be?

Good to know that Andre, thanks. However I've got a patch in my queue which splits the EDITOR command by space anyway. Can anyone see this causing any problems? I gave it reasonable thought and went with "it'll be ok".

At least with the patch the apparently common usecase on mac of "mate -w" (I did this too until recently) will work.
I think you need to update Keg#link and prune as well (see http://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/commit/947a1c7f69605e7afa9432b959976c9967245a4d).

Just: "git config --global github.user" returns "josh"

review_comments.body: As one of maintainers of `ruby-build`, I don't want to see this go into homebrew yet. Its not quite ready. I plan to submit it eventually.

commit_comments.body: It will work with more than one remote. But more than one github remote may return unexpected results. On solution could be to additionally grep for 'origin'. But eventually josh's solution is the most stable one.
I'd liked to add test coverage, but I was a bit unsure on how you'd want that. I was thinking unit tests which would stub the backtick method :` to return different models and verify the results.

Yeah I agree, and especially with the comment in test_hw_model. The only reason I'd write tests in these cases, would be so a rewrite later on will be easier for whoever does so.

Hehehehe, it might be that your body is trying to tell you something ;)

@mxcl RubyCocoa will always use a bit of CPU, this should get better once MacRuby is stable enough and comes with the system.

@adamv Hmm, are you using the system RubyCocoa version? And on what kind of machine is this? (the percentage estimation I gave was on a macbook c2d 2GHz.

Aha! :)

However, this means that it's watching for changes in those directories even when not actively installing anything. We should fix that imo. Will try to figure out how this mythical interactive shell works later on :)

Also, is there like a #homebrew irc channel? Or are you guys not on IRC? (which I could totally understand)

Actually, I already made it so the first time that it would only run whilst actually running "install-just-one". Max, was there a specific reason to move this to "install"? Because now it indeed keeps on running until the parents "install" is finished, so I feel strongly about wrapping "install-just-one"'s body again.

Snow Leopard comes with 1.8.7 by default and Leopard has 1.8.6, so you don't need to install 1.8.x on either.

1.9.1 should have some love.
guys, tons of stuff breaks if your editor has args... this is why the mate command acts like "mate -w" if you symlink it to "mate_wait", and then set EDITOR=mate_wait

Makes sense. Thanks!
If `colpack` supplies libraries that Adol-C needs at runtime (i.e. `.dylib`), this shouldn't be flagged as `:build`.

Replace these with `ENV.universal_binary`

Actually, just:

``` ruby
ENV.universal_binary if ARGV.build_universal?
```
Correct thing to do would be `include.install Dir['uulib/*.h']`

Can't put things into HOMEBREW_PREFIX like this, they won't get cleaned up on upgrades/uninstalls.
And then this can just be `--includedir=#{include}`.
Need to add `inreplace 'Makefile', 'man/man7', 'share/man/man7'` here so that `utf.7` manpage gets installed correctly.
Nit: add a space after `<`.

can get away without escaping slashes here:

```
irb(main):002:0> arg.match 'https:\/\/github.com\/\w+\/homebrew\/(pull\/(\d+)|commit\/\w{4,40})'
=> #<MatchData "https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/pull/7211" 1:"pull/7211" 2:"7211">
irb(main):003:0> arg.match 'https://github.com/\w+/homebrew/(pull/(\d+)|commit/\w{4,40})'
=> #<MatchData "https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/pull/7211" 1:"pull/7211" 2:"7211">
```

`GitDownloadStrategy#initialize` fails if a name isn't passed to `Formula#initialize`, because it has a guard clause checking for `name == '__UNKNOWN__'`. The `CurlDownloadStrategy` doesn't have the same issue, which is why this worked perfectly fine until now.
There is actually a Makefile one-liner to also accomplish this. We chose instead to provide model code in this formula for handling a newer version of a dependency, through Homebrew.
Done. I think this came from the template, for what that's worth.
